content.title: マイクロソフト、顔認識技術の悪用を阻止しようとする倫理的原則を採用 - ロイター
content.desc: Microsoft Corp on Thursday announced ethical principles for the use of its facial recognition technology, saying it would bar such technology from being used to engage in unlawful discrimination and would encourage customers to be transparent when deploying such services. In a blog post on Thursday, Microsoft President Brad Smith pushed for urgency in regulating facial-recognition technology, while adding that tech companies should self regulate too. "We believe it's important for governments in 2019 to start adopting laws to regulate this technology. The facial recognition genie, so to spe...

content.title: Googleのピクセルスレート：素晴らしいChromebook、それほど素晴らしいiPad / Surfaceライバル -  Fast Company
content.desc: Since their 2011 launch, Chromebooks have been synonymous with low-cost, easily managed laptops that have strong appeal for education. But in 2013, when Google shipped the first Chromebook Pixel–a premium machine with a touchscreen–it became clear that the company was intent on exploring new frontiers for its browser-centric Chrome OS operating system. Google’s new Pixel Slate tablet, which starts at $599, represents the culmination of those efforts. With its minimalist operating system and minimalist form factor, it’s the best pure web tablet ever made. But the Pixel Slate also offers the ...

content.title: インテルを目指して、クアルコムはビジネスPC向けチップを発売 - ロイター
content.desc: Qualcomm Inc (QCOM.O: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz), the biggest supplier of chips for mobile phones, on Thursday pushed further into the PC market with a line of chips designed to power business machines. Qualcomm's "Snapdragon" processor chips historically have been at the heart of mobile phones like Alphabet Inc's (GOOGL.O: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz) Google Pixel phone and many Samsung Electronics Co Ltd (005930.KS: Quote, Profile, Research, Stock Buzz) devices. Over the past year, though, Qualcomm adapted its chips to operate PCs running Microsoft Corp's (MSFT.O: Quot...

content.title: Google Chromeのコードは、次のMicrosoft Edgeブラウザ - フォーブス
content.desc: Once upon a time, Internet Explorer ruled the World Wide Web. As time went on, IE languished and was knocked off its perch by Firefox and Google Chrome. Then Microsoft fought back with a new browser called Edge. Image: Microsoft Edge was new inside and out, built to provide the best browsing experience on Windows 10. That was three years ago. Today, despite the fact that it’s an excellent browser, Edge is still struggling to draw much of a crowd. Clearly Microsoft decided that it was time for a dramatic shift in strategy. The company has announced that it’s going to completely overhaul Edge...

content.title: マイクロソフト、新しいWindows 10アップデートで旗艦PCを破る - フォーブス
content.desc: Some Surface Book 2 owners may be a bit grumpy this week after a routine Windows 10 cumulative update left their shiny convertible laptops displaying nothing more than a BSOD. It’s yet another black eye on what has been a ceaseless string of problematic Windows 10 updates over the last several months. From the infamous file-deleting bug and breaking Windows Media Player and iCloud, to buggy default apps and broken audio, Microsoft has been proving its critics right: the process and speed of rolling out new Windows updates and features needs a deep overhaul. Microsoft Surface Book 2 The culp...

content.title: MicrosoftがWindows Tech Supportで傷つけるScammers  -  Forbes
content.desc: Have you ever seen an alert telling you to call for Windows tech support? Or gotten a phone call out of the blue from someone claiming to work for Microsoft? They’ve been a persistent menace for years, but Microsoft is fighting back. Hard. Photo credit: Getty Last week, police in India staged coordinated raids on shady tech support call centers. 100 officers descended on 16 different facilities. The raids resulted in the arrest of 39 individuals who had pretended to be employees of Microsoft, HP, Dell, Google, and even Apple to defraud victims overseas. According to Ajay Pal Sharma, Senior ...

content.title: マイクロソフトでは、顔認識技術が市民の自由を侵食することを懸念しています -  Fast Company
content.desc: AI Now, a New York University-affiliated public interest group that counts employees of Microsoft and Google as its members, has raised the alarm over the inevitable uses of facial recognition technologies by governments and law enforcement agencies that, they believe, will erode our civil liberties, reports the Verge. In a paper published on Thursday, AI Now warns of the U.S. becoming a China-like surveillance state thanks to facial recognition tech. In China, the technology is already being used to publicly shame people in debt, track minorities, and block people from entering certain hou...

content.title: 世界で最も貴重なハイテク企業であることは、Appleと競合しています.MarkWatch
content.desc: THERESE POLETTI'S TECH TALES By Therese Poletti Microsoft and Amazon are challenging Apple for top spot, and Google isn’t far behind In Tuesday trading, Microsoft and Apple were trading the market-cap lead back and forth as Amazon remained close and Google brought up the rear. MarketWatch photo illustration/Getty Images, iStockphoto, Bloomberg After nearly a decade of Apple Inc. dominance, there is an evolving four-way race among the top tech giants that is pitting the cash cow against a trio of cloud-computing colossuses. content.title: ホワイトハウス、将来の技術幹部と会談 - ロイター
content.desc: The Trump administration, which has had strained relations with technology companies, met on Thursday with top tech executives to discuss ways to "ensure American dominance" of innovation and the future of high tech jobs. content.title: マイクロソフト、Azureクラウドのための機械学習にもっと力を注ぐ -  Forbes
content.desc: Nicolo Fusi works in the automated machine learning research team at Microsoft Research The discussion has been open for a while now. We know we want Machine Learning (ML) to be able to drive the Artificial Intelligence (AI) and smart automation that we demand in tomorrow’s software — but how do we build, train and further educate the ML brains we seek to now bring forward? Computer brains are built with models that are exposed to datasets, which are then trained, tested and enriched over time as they learn what’s right, what’s wrong and ultimately what is altogether culturally and ethicall...
